message.title: (!) Boudica Defeated (!)
message.subtitle: Suetonius Crushes the Revolt
message.text: @G[c3 stills_108.png]@L @H Message @L This is a historical message of no gameplay significance. Attacks will continue, so as to provide challenging gameplay. @L@L @H Historical Background @L One year after the revolt began, the Roman general Suetonius utterly crushed the Iceni army, ending the uprising. Boudica later took her own life with poison and Roman forces reclaimed the province. However, the devastation that the revolt had caused was immense. Over 70,000 Romans and their Briton subjects were killed, and the largest cities in Roman Britain, including Londinium, were depopulated and razed. @L@L The scale and nature of cruelty against civilians was unimaginable. Local soldiers valiantly attempted to defend civilians, often holding out for weeks inside temples or fortresses before being overwhelmed and slaughtered. Many Iceni looted Roman arms and armor and used them against the legions. Many of the settlers were retired Roman army veterans and, though aged, rallied under Suetonius, bolstering his numbers. Records written by Cassius Dio and Tacitus concerning the revolt portray the Iceni committing some of the worst acts of violence in all recorded history. @L@L Roman Emperor Nero even considered abandoning the entire island during the revolt when it seemed all was lost before the surprising news of Suetonius' victory arrived. @L@L The uprising came about due to the Romans' scornful dealings with the Iceni. They were treated as slaves even though they had peacefully entered into an association with Rome as part of an inheritance pact at the death of the king of the Iceni, Boudica's husband. The Roman forces ignored the king's will and violently seized Iceni lands, took slaves, flogged the queen, and raped her daughters. Even after such overt disrespect and oppression, Roman rulers ignored the signs of mounting unrest, allowing the situation to escalate into unprecedented disaster. @L@L Suetonius was convinced that they would be defeated as the enemy advantages seemed insurmountable. His speech is often portrayed more flamboyantly but the most likely accurate version is as follows: @L@L "Ignore the racket made by these savages. There are more women than men in their ranks. They are not soldiers - they are not even properly equipped. We have beaten them before and when they see our weapons and feel our spirit, they will crack. Stick together. Throw the javelins, then push forward: knock them down with your shields and finish them off with your swords. Forget about plunder. Just win and you will have everything." @L@L After the battle turned into a rout, the Briton army was unable to disengage as their own wagons for supply and spectators blocked escape. Romans killed every person and animal that could be found in the Briton camp and on the battlefield, putting a brutal end to one of the most violent revolts in Roman history. @L@L@L@L
